Description: Lower wall sherd of Attic black-figured pottery skyphos; interior glazed; exterior: at top, black-figure decoration consisting of possible maenad (feet and lower part of chiton remaining) to right; below, glazed save for a reserved band.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit suggests that the lack of added white for female flesh is first observed in circa 500BC, the date she suggests for this sherd. Skyphoi from the Haimon Group, which last until circa 480BC also sometimes omit added colour for flesh. For parallels, see Moore and Pease Philippides, 'The Athenian Agora, xxiii. Attic Black-Figured Pottery', 1986, no. 1532.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 87 no. 292 pl. 65)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 365, no. B486, pl. XXVI, pl. CLXXXIV)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1269) (phase 3)
